G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over the custody and parenting-time orders concerning the minor child pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, §§ 10, 20; and the Massachusetts Child Custody Jurisdiction Act, G.L. c. 209B, because Massachusetts is and has been the child’s “home state.”

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7\u00a7 10, 20.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over the custody and parenting-time orders concerning the minor child pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, §§ 10, 20; and the Massachusetts Child Custody Jurisdiction Act, G.L. c. 209B, because Massachusetts is and has been the child’s “home state.”

G.L. c. 209B.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over the custody and parenting-time orders concerning the minor child pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, §§ 10, 20; and the Massachusetts Child Custody Jurisdiction Act, G.L. c. 209B, because Massachusetts is and has been the child’s “home state.”

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 3.proposition: Venue is proper in the Middlesex Probate and Family Court because the prior judgment was entered here and the minor child resides in Middlesex County. See G.L. c. 215, § 3; G.L. c. 208, §§ 5, 28.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 5, 28.proposition: Venue is proper in the Middlesex Probate and Family Court because the prior judgment was entered here and the minor child resides in Middlesex County. See G.L. c. 215, § 3; G.L. c. 208, §§ 5, 28.

*Schuh v. Schuh*, 453 Mass. 546 (2009).proposition: This Complaint seeks modification only of custody/parenting-time and related conditions, based upon a material and substantial change in circumstances affecting the best interests and safety of the minor child since entry of the Existing Custody Order. See G.L. c. 208, § 28; *Schuh v. Schuh*, 453 Mass. 546 (2009); *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).
*Schuh v. Schuh*, 453 Mass. 546 (2009).support_reasoning: The proposition concerns modification of custody/parenting time under G.L. c. 208, § 28 and the standard of a material and substantial change in circumstances affecting the child’s best interests and safety. Schuh v. Schuh, 453 Mass. 546 (2009), as provided, is a G.L. c. 123A sexually dangerous person commitment/discharge case and does not involve domestic relations, custody, parenting time, or § 28. Its holding addresses the role of qualified examiners and the CAB in SDP proceedings, not custody modification standards, so it does not support the cited proposition.
*Schuh v. Schuh*, 453 Mass. 546 (2009).relevant_excerpt: This case concerns the interplay between the role of the qualified examiners and that of the community access board (CAB) in discharge proceedings for sexually dangerous persons pursuant to G. L. c. 123A, § 9. … We hold that, in order for the Commonwealth to proceed to trial in a discharge proceeding under G. L. c. 123A, § 9, at least one of the two qualified examiners must opine that the petitioner remains sexually dangerous.

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: This Complaint seeks modification only of custody/parenting-time and related conditions, based upon a material and substantial change in circumstances affecting the best interests and safety of the minor child since entry of the Existing Custody Order. See G.L. c. 208, § 28; *Schuh v. Schuh*, 453 Mass. 546 (2009); *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: Mason v. Coleman addresses the standard under G.L. c. 208, § 30 for removal of children from the Commonwealth in a joint physical custody situation, focusing on the “best interests” test for relocation. It does not concern a complaint seeking modification solely of custody/parenting time due to a material and substantial change in circumstances under G.L. c. 208, § 28. The proposition about modification standards and changed circumstances is therefore not what Mason decides or discusses; Mason is a relocation/removal case, not a § 28 modification standard case.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 30, governs removal from the Commonwealth of children of divorced parents where one of the parents seeks to relocate without the consent of the other parent. Removal of the children may be authorized by the court only ‘upon cause shown,’ meaning a showing that removal is in the children’s best interests. … Today we consider the appropriate standard where parents have joint physical and legal custody. We conclude that in such a situation ‘cause shown’ pursuant to G. L. c. 208, § 30, means a showing that removal is in the ‘best interests’ of the children…”

*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.proposition: Massachusetts courts have long held that the paramount concern in custody matters is the best interests of the child. See *Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985); *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 843–844 (2003); G.L. c. 208, § 31.
*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely states that in removal and custody determinations “the best interests of the child” are the governing standard and describes them as the “paramount concern.” The court interprets the governing statute (G.L. c. 208, § 30) as requiring that removal be in the child’s best interests and then explains that all relevant interests must be evaluated with that paramount concern in mind. This directly supports the proposition that Massachusetts courts treat the child’s best interests as the paramount concern in custody matters.
*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that… [t]he words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined… Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern…”

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 843\u2.proposition: Massachusetts courts have long held that the paramount concern in custody matters is the best interests of the child. See *Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985); *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 843–844 (2003); G.L. c. 208, § 31.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 843\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion directly traces the history of the ‘best interests of the child’ standard in Massachusetts custody law, states that it has long been used in Massachusetts to decide custody and visitation, and quotes prior cases (including Yannas) that describe the child’s welfare/best interests as the paramount concern. Thus, the case affirmatively supports the proposition that Massachusetts courts have long held that the paramount concern in custody matters is the best interests of the child.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 843\u2.relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… The ‘best interests’ standard appeared in our case law at least as early as 1865… It has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., Blixt v. Blixt… (best interests standard ‘has long been used in Massachusetts to decide issues of custody and visitation’); Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985) (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’).”

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: Massachusetts courts have long held that the paramount concern in custody matters is the best interests of the child. See *Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985); *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 843–844 (2003); G.L. c. 208, § 31.

*Adoption of Katharine*, 42 Mass. App. C.proposition: A parent’s substance abuse, intoxication, or impaired functioning while caring for a child can constitute a material and substantial change in circumstances warranting modification where it affects the child’s safety, stability, or welfare. See, e.g., *Adoption of Katharine*, 42 Mass. App. Ct. 25, 29–31 (1997) (parent’s substance abuse relevant to parental fitness and child’s welfare); *Adoption of Quentin*, 424 Mass. 882, 886–888 (1997).
*Adoption of Katharine*, 42 Mass. App. C.support_reasoning: The case concerns termination of parental rights and holds that cocaine addiction, standing alone and without demonstrated past neglect or abuse, does not automatically establish legal unfitness. The court explicitly rejects predicting future harm based solely on parental drug use where the evidence shows the child has received minimally acceptable care. Thus, rather than endorsing substance abuse as a sufficient material change affecting the child’s welfare, the opinion requires an evidentiary link between the addiction and harm or risk of harm to the child, so it does not support the broad proposition cited.
*Adoption of Katharine*, 42 Mass. App. C.relevant_excerpt: “In the absence of a history of unacceptable care or testimony from an expert that child abuse and neglect is the inevitable end result of a cocaine habit, the prediction that such will occur is impermissible speculation. … [W]e do not think a cocaine habit, without more, translates automatically into legal unfitness to act as a parent.”

*Adoption of Quentin*, 424 Mass. 882, 88.proposition: A parent’s substance abuse, intoxication, or impaired functioning while caring for a child can constitute a material and substantial change in circumstances warranting modification where it affects the child’s safety, stability, or welfare. See, e.g., *Adoption of Katharine*, 42 Mass. App. Ct. 25, 29–31 (1997) (parent’s substance abuse relevant to parental fitness and child’s welfare); *Adoption of Quentin*, 424 Mass. 882, 886–888 (1997).
*Adoption of Quentin*, 424 Mass. 882, 88.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with termination of parental rights based on parental unfitness and does not analyze modification or material/substantial change in circumstances. While it notes that the father used public assistance funds to purchase drugs and that the home was unsafe and unsanitary, it does not frame substance abuse or intoxication as a change in circumstances warranting modification of an existing order. Thus, it does not provide authority for the specific modification-focused proposition stated, even though it is consistent with the broader idea that substance-related conduct can bear on parental fitness and child welfare.
*Adoption of Quentin*, 424 Mass. 882, 88.relevant_excerpt: We conclude that there was adequate evidence to support the findings that: the parents maintained an unsafe and unsanitary home and failed to take steps to correct these conditions; the parents lived an itinerant lifestyle which was harmful to the children; they neglected the emotional well-being of the children; the father never displayed a long-term commitment to stay with the family; the father used the public assistance funds to purchase drugs; the mother lacked the ability to protect the children from the father’s harmful conduct; and the mother lacked the capacity to deal with the needs of the children.

*Custody of a Minor*, 389 Mass. 755, 766.proposition: Changes in a parent’s ability to provide a safe and stable home, including evidence of alcohol or drug misuse, are properly considered as material changes affecting the child’s best interests. See *Custody of a Minor*, 389 Mass. 755, 766–767 (1983); *Care & Protection of Olga*, 57 Mass. App. Ct. 821, 825–827 (2003).
*Custody of a Minor*, 389 Mass. 755, 766.support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss changes in a parent’s ability to provide a safe and stable home, nor does it address alcohol or drug misuse as a factor in custody determinations. Instead, it focuses on procedural errors and the general constitutional and statutory standards of parental unfitness and best interests, emphasizing that unconventional lifestyle alone is not a proper basis for removing custody. There is no language about material changes in circumstances or substance misuse affecting best interests, so the case does not support the specific proposition cited.
*Custody of a Minor*, 389 Mass. 755, 766.relevant_excerpt: “‘State intervention in the parent-child relationship is justified only when parents appear unable to provide for their children’s care and protection.’ … ‘Clearly, under the test our cases articulate, the State may not deprive parents of the custody of their children merely because they are poor and cannot offer the child certain material advantages, or because they choose or suffer an unusual life style. It is not the quality or character of parental conduct per se that justifies State intervention… Rather, it is the fact of the endangerment itself.’”

*Care & Protection of Olga*, 57 Mass. Ap.raw_text: *Care & Protection of Olga*, 57 Mass. App. Ct. 821, 825–827 (2003)
*Care & Protection of Olga*, 57 Mass. Ap.proposition: Changes in a parent’s ability to provide a safe and stable home, including evidence of alcohol or drug misuse, are properly considered as material changes affecting the child’s best interests. See *Custody of a Minor*, 389 Mass. 755, 766–767 (1983); *Care & Protection of Olga*, 57 Mass. App. Ct. 821, 825–827 (2003).
*Care & Protection of Olga*, 57 Mass. Ap.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely treats the parents’ drug addiction and resulting instability as central to the unfitness and best-interests analysis, emphasizing the impact of years of neglect and abuse tied to substance abuse and domestic violence. It also notes the parents’ subsequent progress in treatment but holds that this improvement does not bar consideration of past conduct in predicting future fitness and determining the children’s best interests. Although the case does not use the phrase “material change,” its reasoning supports considering changes in a parent’s ability to provide a safe, stable, and drug‑free home as critical to the best‑interests inquiry.
*Care & Protection of Olga*, 57 Mass. Ap.relevant_excerpt: “Fairly construed, the record reveals a family that was profoundly affected by drug abuse and domestic violence, the effects of which left the three children with an intense need for care, attention, and therapy. During the approximately two years between the time of the department’s initial intervention and the time of trial, the parents had made progress in dealing with their difficulties… Although that progress, and its impact on the likelihood of future fitness, require recognition… that progress does not preclude consideration of past behavior as a means of predicting the likely future… In the end, the children’s best interests are of paramount importance.”

*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 595\.proposition: These new facts directly implicate Ethan’s safety and emotional well‑being during Father’s overnight parenting time, which is central to any custody and parenting‑time analysis. See *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 595–596 (1996) (court must focus on whether living arrangements and parental conduct serve child’s best interests); *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. at 843–844.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 595\.support_reasoning: The proposition cites Custody of Vaughn for the principle that, in custody and parenting‑time determinations, the court must focus on whether living arrangements and parental conduct serve the child’s best interests, including safety and emotional well‑being. Vaughn expressly emphasizes that domestic violence and its effects on the child are central to custody analysis and requires explicit findings on how such conduct affects the child and the appropriateness of the custody arrangement. That directly aligns with using the case to ground a best‑interests, safety‑focused analysis of a parent’s time with the child.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 595\.relevant_excerpt: “We agree with the Appeals Court that the judge below ‘fail[ed] to make detailed and comprehensive findings of fact on the issues of domestic violence and its effect upon the child as well as upon the father’s parenting ability.’ … The Probate Court failed to consider the special risks to the child in awarding custody to a father who had committed acts of violence against the mother.… Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.”

*B.B.V. v. B.N.V.*, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 12.proposition: The pattern of Ethan’s Monday‑morning exhaustion, as reported by his school, further demonstrates that Father’s home environment during parenting time may lack appropriate structure, rest, and supervision, and that the current parenting schedule may be detrimental to Ethan’s health and school functioning. See *B.B.V. v. B.N.V.*, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 12, 20–21 (2007) (child’s stability and adjustment to school and routine are important in best‑interests analysis).
*B.B.V. v. B.N.V.*, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 12.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on comparing two parents’ overall custodial fitness, emphasizing stability, continuity with the primary caregiver, and future risk from exposure to an incestuous relationship. It does not discuss a child’s exhaustion, school functioning, or a parenting schedule being detrimental to health or school performance. While it generally notes that stability and continuity with a primary caregiver are important in the best-interests analysis, it does not specifically link school adjustment or routine-based fatigue to a finding that a particular home environment or schedule is harmful.
*B.B.V. v. B.N.V.*, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 12.relevant_excerpt: The wife would provide the children with the consistent living arrangement and the willingness to foster contact with both parents recommended by the MSPCC psychologist (a stability and a willingness that would not be provided by the husband). See Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 842 (2003) (stability and continuity with primary caregiver an important factor in custody).

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28, 31.proposition: Ensuring that parenting time occurs in a safe and sober environment is squarely within the Court’s authority when fashioning custody and parenting‑time orders. See G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31; *Blixt v. Blixt*, 437 Mass. 649, 658–659 (2002) (court may place appropriate conditions on visitation to safeguard child’s welfare); *Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 493–495 (2012).

*Blixt v. Blixt*, 437 Mass. 649, 658\u20.proposition: Ensuring that parenting time occurs in a safe and sober environment is squarely within the Court’s authority when fashioning custody and parenting‑time orders. See G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31; *Blixt v. Blixt*, 437 Mass. 649, 658–659 (2002) (court may place appropriate conditions on visitation to safeguard child’s welfare); *Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 493–495 (2012).
*Blixt v. Blixt*, 437 Mass. 649, 658\u20.support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Blixt concerns the constitutionality and construction of the grandparent visitation statute and the required showing of harm, not the court’s authority to require that parenting time occur in a safe and sober environment or to impose safety-related conditions on a parent’s visitation. It discusses conditions and standards for third‑party (grandparent) visitation orders, not custody or parenting‑time orders between parents, and does not mention sobriety, safety conditions, or supervised visitation. Thus, it does not provide direct authority for the specific proposition cited.
*Blixt v. Blixt*, 437 Mass. 649, 658\u20.relevant_excerpt: “More specifically, to succeed, the grandparents must allege and prove that the failure to grant visitation will cause the child significant harm by adversely affecting the child’s health, safety, or welfare.… Imposition of the standards just stated…ensures a careful balance between the possibly conflicting rights of parents in securing their parental autonomy, and the best interests of children in avoiding actual harm to their well-being.” (437 Mass. at 658–659).

*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 493\u20.proposition: Ensuring that parenting time occurs in a safe and sober environment is squarely within the Court’s authority when fashioning custody and parenting‑time orders. See G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31; *Blixt v. Blixt*, 437 Mass. 649, 658–659 (2002) (court may place appropriate conditions on visitation to safeguard child’s welfare); *Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 493–495 (2012).
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 493\u20.support_reasoning: The excerpts of Hunter v. Rose provided focus on recognition of California registered domestic partnerships, parentage presumptions, best‑interests custody analysis, and attorney’s fees. They do not discuss imposing conditions on parenting time or requiring that visitation occur in a ‘safe and sober’ or otherwise specifically conditioned environment. Because the opinion does not address judicial authority to structure or condition parenting time in the manner described, it does not support the specific proposition for which it is cited.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 493\u20.relevant_excerpt: “Parents have an equal right to custody of their children. … ‘In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is] … what is ‘best for the child’…. The judge shall consider ‘whether or not the child’s present or past living conditions adversely affect his physical, mental, moral or emotional health.’ G. L. c. 208, § 31.” (463 Mass. at 494)
